Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phenological shifts in seed-dispersal networks of the Sierra Nevada, California
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many recreational and cultural events are based on the seasonal timing of natural events. For example, visitors flock to New England to enjoy fall leaf colors and birdwatchers congregate in May to welcome migrating birds. Seasonal timing also matters to plants and animals. To fuel their fall migrations, birds rely on calorie-rich wild fruits. Likewise, the plants that make those fruits rely on migrating birds to carry their seeds to places where they can grow into new plants. This mutually beneficial interaction works because the timing of wild fruit production matches the timing of bird migration. In many places, however, the seasonal timing of bird migration and fruit production has become misaligned. With not enough fruit to fuel their migratory flights, birds may suffer during migration. And, without birds to disperse their seeds, some plants could fail to produce the next generation. This research will measure how much fruit production and bird migration are misaligned. Investigators will study the environmental cues for fall migration and fruit production as well as the factors that control how many fruits are produced by wild plants. Members of the public will participate by providing observations on bird-fruit interactions and will learn about scientific research through field trips led by the investigators.

The relationships between environmental cues and fall seasonal events in birds and plants remain largely unexplored. This project will use multi-year, multi-species, publicly available datasets to estimate year-to-year differences in the timing of fall migration in birds and fruiting in fleshy-fruited shrubs. Two methods will be employed to determine relationships. First, researchers will use Bayesian survival models to regress data on yearly timing of migration and fruiting from the National Phenology Network and eBird, respectively, with data on environmental drivers. Second, a common garden experiment with five genera of shrubs will be set up to mechanistically determine for the first time how increased temperature, drought, and the interaction between the temperature and drought affect the timing and abundance of fruits. Results will be useful in predicting the ability of birds to migrate and fruiting-plants to disperse their seeds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how climatic conditions like increased temperature and reduced precipitation affect the timing of two fall natural events: fruit ripening in wild plants and bird migration. These events are connected because migratory birds rely on fruits for food, and the plants rely on birds to carry the seeds encased within the fruits to new locations. Our project focused on the Sierra Nevada mountains in California, which have a high diversity of plants that produce fruits that are eaten by birds.

One goal of the project was to subject growing plants to increased temperature and/or drought, while tracking when plants fruited and how many fruits they produced. We grew these fleshy-fruited plants in a common garden experiment in the eastern Sierra Nevada mountains, California (Figure 1). We tracked fruiting timing and number of fruits for each of six plant species. Neither higher temperature nor drought significantly affected the timing of fruit ripening within the experiment. Drought did not significantly affect the number of fruits produced. However, individuals subjected to high temperatures produced more fruits and held onto these fruits longer than individuals at control temperatures. Temperatures 1-2 degrees C higher than average may increase the ability of certain plant individuals to produce and retain fruits. However, our experiment could not determine whether this increased production and retention reaches a threshold at higher temperatures, such as those predicted by the end of the decade.

Additionally, we collected a variety of leaf traits from each of our plants. We are currently working on analyzing this trait data to determine how the combination of higher temperature and drought affects growth within plants. 

The second goal of the project was to determine if the timing of fruit ripening and migration had changed in recent years. We used multi-year, multi-species datasets of observations collected by citizen scientist from the National Phenology Network and eBird. Migration timing data for bird species was drawn from sightings recorded in eBird. Fruiting timing data for plant species was taken from the National Phenology Network database. Both fruiting plants and migratory birds in the Sierra Nevada mountains have delayed the timing of these natural fall events, with plants fruiting a few days later and birds remaining a few days later (Figure 2).

We are working on incorporating weather station data from previous years into these analyses to determine how temperature and precipitation affect the timing of both fruit ripening and migration. This will allow us to understand whether birds and plants respond to similar weather conditions for the timing of these events.

During the grant period, and continuing after it, the Ph.D. student provided an internship for a female high school student, who gained experience doing scientific research. The Ph.D. student on this project taught groups of elementary school children about how to do scientific experiments in general and about this plant experiment in particular. She worked with natural history educators in the eastern Sierra Nevada to continue this educational exercise with other groups of K-12 students. She additionally engaged with a group of citizen scientists interested in the timing of natural events within the eastern Sierra Nevada.

This project contributed towards the dissertation research of one Ph.D. student, who is now a postdoctoral scholar at Northern Arizona University.
